quote: In a religious context, a covenant refers to an agreement a group of believers feels their deity has made with them.
explanation: Frames settlement and government as divinely authorized—key logic behind claiming and ruling non-Christian lands (Doctrine of Discovery).

quote: They believed that they were called by their god to create a new place where they could practice their own religion without having to live among those who did not believe as they did.
explanation: Religious ‘calling’ justifies founding colonies and exercising authority over an already-inhabited place.

quote: Both groups viewed the “New World” as a place where they could do that.
explanation: Treats the land as available for English projects, erasing Native sovereignty—core to the Doctrine of Discovery mindset.

quote: loyal subjects of the king of England
explanation: Asserts English royal sovereignty over the territory claimed by settlers.
Declares a right to plant an English colony, a Discovery-era claim of possession.

quote: in a covenant that would be governed by “just and equal laws” that they promised to obey
explanation: Links divine covenant to civil authority; settlers claim the right to legislate and rule.

quote: The Puritans saw the Indigenous people as incapable of salvation but still in need of aid, as the colony’s official seal suggests.
explanation: Christianizing/paternalist rationale that often accompanied Discovery claims.

quote: Humans do not have free will and do not determine the course of their own lives. Everything that happens is the will of God.
People’s salvation is predestined, already decided by God, and has nothing to do with their actions while on earth.
Certain individuals are “called” by God and are among the “elect.”
explanation: Idea of the elect; spiritual hierarchy.

quote: One is born as part of the elect or not, according to God’s will.
Outward good fortune, especially material wealth, is a sign of God’s favor.
explanation: Prosperity interpreted as proof of election; moralizes success.

quote: Obeying lawful authority, even when one disagrees with it, is a sign of being one of the elect.
explanation: Religious sanction for strict social order and deference to colonial authority.

quote: Bad luck, poverty, and a rebellious attitude are all evidence of damnation.
explanation: Theological justification for inequality and suppression of dissent.

quote: When the Mayflower landed at Cape Cod in 1620, forty-one of the men on board wrote an agreement for how their colony would operate.
explanation: Covenant politics in action; self-government begins with a religiously framed compact.

quote: This Mayflower Compact invoked their god’s name and declared that they and their fellow passengers on the Mayflower were …
explanation: Religious covenant explicitly undergirds civic order in the new colony.

quote: Ten years later in 1630, Massachusetts Bay Colony was founded by the Puritans.
explanation: Direct link from Calvinist Pilgrim/Puritan beliefs to founding a new colony.

quote: This colony had two purposes. One goal was to establish trade in goods produced in the colonies.
explanation: Economic purpose of Massachusetts Bay’s foundation.

quote: But it was also meant to be a godly community, a religious home for the Puritans, who did not tolerate dissenting views on spiritual matters.
explanation: Calvinist ideas shape a disciplined, theologically uniform society.
